results.title: Electrochemical cells
results.creator_credit: J. Arthur Campbell, David W. Ridgway and Wexler Film Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Chemical Education Material Study Series”.
Shows construction and operation of an electrochemical cel1. Time lapse photography of the charges at the electrodes and animated diagrams of the cell processes show the nature of the electrode reactions, the motion of electron and ion currents and the relationship between concentrations and cell voltage Suitable for upper secondary levels.
results.creator_credit_for_label: J. Arthur Campbell, David W. Ridgway and Wexler Film Productions

results.title: Chemical families
results.creator_credit: J. Arthur Campbell, David W. Ridgway and Davidson Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Chemical Education Material Study Series”.
Starting with a display of samples of over 70 elements, the film demonstrates methods by which chemical similarities among the elements have provided the basis for dividing them logically into families. By experiment and observation metals, non-metals, and the doubtful elements are grouped. The film demonstrates how atomic numbers have provided the key to the ordering of the elements in the periodic table.

results.title: Charley's march of time
results.creator_credit: Joy Batchelor, John Halas and Halas and Batchelor Cartoon Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Charley”.
One of a cartoon series featuring the character “Charley”. In this film Charley questions the need for the National Insurance Acts of 1948, and by way of answer, he is taken back through the ages and shown how one man’s search for security has led him from one piece of social legislation to another. Animators: Wally Crook, Vera Linnecar, E. Williams and R. Privett.

results.title: Charley junior's schooldays
results.creator_credit: Joy Batchelor, John Halas and Halas and Batchelor Cartoon Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “Charley”.
Features the Education Act of 1944 and the improvements which may be expected in British education as a result of the Act. Charley Junior, a cartoon character, is eager to know about this future life. A nurse tells him about his school days; the different types of schools he will attend; the increase in education facilities and improvements in method; plans for the training of teachers and the construction of new schools. Voice: Max Adrian.

results.title: Charley's black magic
results.creator_credit: Joy Batchelor, John Halas and Halas and Batchelor Cartoon Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Charley”.
A “Charley” cartoon showing the fundamental importance to the national economy of a plentiful supply of cheap coal. Britain’s source is at present coal but it is not cheap and to remedy the situation there is need for development and re-organisation of mines. The problem of finding enough money for this task will necessitate an increase in the cost of coal, but this situation will be improved as mines become more productive. Voices: Harold Berens, Jack Train.

results.title: Your very good health
results.creator_credit: Joy Batchelor, John Halas and Halas and Batchelor Cartoon Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Charley”.
A cartoon illustrating various aspects of Britain’s National Health Service Scheme. Discusses in particular the effect of the scheme on the average British family.

results.title: La-bas seur ces montagnes. Trois canards.
results.creator_credit: Norman McLaren, Cine-Photographie and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Chants populaires”.
Animated scenes illustrate two French folk songs. ‘La-bas sur ces montaignes’ 3.13 mins. ‘Trois canards’ 2.48 mins. Featuring the Allouette Quartet and L’Assistance.

results.title: Le-haut sur ces montagnes
results.creator_credit: Jean Palardy and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Chants populaires”.
Animated interpretation of the French folk song “La-haut sur ces Montagnes” set on the island of Orleans near Quebec, where traditional dances and songs are kept alive by the peasant community. Featuring Madeleine Lachance and the Quatuor Alouette.
